articles.headline: Bankers Hate the Volcker Rule. Now, It Could Be Watered Down.
articles.snippet: Softening the rule, which prohibits banks from making speculative but profitable wagers, is part of the White House’s deregulatory push.
articles.abstract: Softening the rule, which prohibits banks from making speculative but profitable wagers, is part of the White House’s deregulatory push.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was one of the most significant actions by the federal government to prevent a repeat of the financial crisis.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Trump Team’s Mueller Strategy: Limit the Investigation and Attack the Investigators
articles.snippet: “They have now decided that they need to be more proactive, more aggressive and more anticipatory,” says Alan Dershowitz, the Harvard Law School professor emeritus.
articles.abstract: “They have now decided that they need to be more proactive, more aggressive and more anticipatory,” says Alan Dershowitz, the Harvard Law School professor emeritus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Frustrated and impatient, fed up with waiting and eager to fight back, President Trump has embarked on what amounts to a two-prong strategy to contain the threat and undercut the credibility of the escalating investigations targeting him and his associates.

articles.headline: Chances of China Trade Win Undercut by Trump Team Infighting
articles.snippet: Ceaseless infighting and jockeying for influence on the White House’s trade team helped deprive the president of a quick victory on his most cherished policy issue.
articles.abstract: Ceaseless infighting and jockeying for influence on the White House’s trade team helped deprive the president of a quick victory on his most cherished policy issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By the time American negotiators wrapped up high-level talks with a visiting Chinese delegation last week, President Trump’s ambitions for a multibillion-dollar trade agreement had, for the time being, shriveled into a blandly worded communiqué without any dollar figures. It was not clear that the talks set a path to success.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Ana Swanson

articles.headline: An Artless Negotiation From the President Who Penned ‘The Art of the Deal’
articles.snippet: President Trump’s negotiating playbook is by now pretty obvious: Make big demands, thump your chest and claim victory. But some of his talk on China has a whiff of desperation.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s negotiating playbook is by now pretty obvious: Make big demands, thump your chest and claim victory. But some of his talk on China has a whiff of desperation.
articles.lead_paragraph: So, President Trump suspended his plan — er, threat — to impose some $150 billion in tariffs on China, heading off a trade war. At least for today.

articles.headline: Low-Paid Women Get Hollywood Money to File Harassment Suits
articles.snippet: A case against Walmart is among the first to arise from the Time’s Up Legal Defense Fund, meant to broaden #MeToo beyond celebrities.
articles.abstract: A case against Walmart is among the first to arise from the Time’s Up Legal Defense Fund, meant to broaden #MeToo beyond celebrities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gina Pitre had come to dread working at Walmart. A manager, she said, used to touch her inappropriately and make suggestive comments.

articles.headline: Want to See Your Baby? In China, It Can Cost You
articles.snippet: A hospital demanded that a woman pay her bills before she could see her newborn twins, illustrating a plight that many face in the Chinese medical system.
articles.abstract: A hospital demanded that a woman pay her bills before she could see her newborn twins, illustrating a plight that many face in the Chinese medical system.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANGZHOU, China — A day after Juliana Brandy Logbo gave birth to twins this month through an emergency cesarean section in a Chinese hospital, she thought the worst was over. Then the demands for money began.

articles.headline: Amazon Pushes Facial Recognition to Police. Critics See Surveillance Risk.
articles.snippet: More than two dozen civil rights organizations asked the tech giant to stop selling its image recognition system to law enforcement agencies.
articles.abstract: More than two dozen civil rights organizations asked the tech giant to stop selling its image recognition system to law enforcement agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — In late 2016, Amazon introduced a new online service that could help identify faces and other objects in images, offering it to anyone at a low cost through its giant cloud computing division, Amazon Web Services.
